text:
So let's go ahead and
introduce our speaker today. This is Chris Moran.

We are very lucky
to have him here. He's been a great
partner here at Stanford for our work in defense,
entrepreneurship, and policy

discussions. Chris is the executive
director and general manager of Lockheed Martin Ventures.

It is the venture
capital investment arm of Lockheed Martin Corporation.

Chris is responsible for
leading all the investments in small technology companies
which support the broader

goals of Lockheed Martin. Now, as far as
Lockheed goes, it's been really great to hear
more about that recently

in discussions with Chris and
all the work that they're doing. Their impact is
far and wide, more

than I was tracking at the time. It makes strategic
investments in companies that are developing
cutting edge technologies

in the core businesses
and the new markets that are important to Lockheed. And those portfolio
companies then

get access to engineering,
talent, technologies, research, and the company's international
business relationships.

Before all of that,
Chris actually did similar work at
Applied Materials

where he led Applied Ventures. And he has been active in this
space for a number of years.

He's also a recovering MIT grad
who has come to the Valley and-- The weather is better.

Weather is better. [CHUCKLES] And we are so glad to
have you here at Stanford. And with that, let's
welcome Chris Moran.

Thank you. [APPLAUSE] Welcome, Chris. So as Eric mentioned, you've
been in corporate venture

capital for a number of years. 18 years-- 18 years. --I believe. So from starting the
corporate venture

arm of Applied
Materials, as Eric mentioned, to rebooting the
venture arm of Lockheed Martin,

how did you get into Venture? What attracted you to Venture,
and what led you to the path to where you are today?

It wasn't really
attraction, believe me. I was running a business,
was applied for 30 years.

For most of the time, I was
in engineering operations and management,
general management. And the last business I was in
charge of, I actually closed.

And the CEO said
to me, oh, you've got incredible business acumen. You're the first person to say
we should close this business.
Well, you just fired yourself. What are you going to do? I hadn't thought of it that way. I don't have a job, do I?

He said, well, we want to
start this venture thing. Would you like to do that? I said, OK, great. I knew nothing about
it other than living

in Silicon Valley
for a number of years and keeping up to date on what
Steve Jobs and everyone else

was doing at the time. But I had to do a lot
of learning very fast and started the fund that
applied from that point on.

That's cool. I think most of the VCs I talk
to don't actually want to become VCs, and they fall into it.

But maybe you could share
more about your current role at Lockheed Martin Ventures in
terms of what's the mission?

What stages do you focus on? Maybe share a little
bit more about that. Yeah, absolutely.

So when I got to Lockheed
in 2016, they had a fund,

with $100 million kind of fund. And it was mostly focused on
enterprise business software

and so on. So it was really in support of
the core company's operations, but it wasn't really focused
on the core technology

of the company and what we did. We're a large
aerospace manufacturer. We make the F-35, the F-22, the
F-16, so a lot of fighter jets

and other material like that. So these things need incredible
materials, power systems,

electronic systems. You name it, we're
probably using it. And then we go to
space, and there's propulsion systems and other
things that are in there.

And all that tech is moving
very rapidly, some of which Lockheed can keep pace
with, some of which

we need help by
tapping into startup companies and other
companies to work with. So when I got there,
the mission was

to pivot the fund from doing the
basic enterprise software stuff, to be much more focused on
what the business groups are

concerned about. And there's four
main business groups. They each have very unique
requirements and the products

that they make. So we set up a very regular,
a monthly cadence of meeting with key people in
the business units

to understand what
their key needs were, what their strategies were,
how we could best fit.

And then we tried to
position the venture group. Turned out to work out pretty
well because you guys know what the Horizons are.

Horizon 1 is the
annual operating plan. Everyone knows what that is. Horizon 2 in Lockheed speak
is the long range plan,

which is three years. That's not very long range,
but it's three years. And what we find is that the
business units are basically

blind at three years and a day. So anything is happening
in three years and a day, they don't know about it. And most venture companies take
about three years to mature.

So it turns out what we work on
and the companies work with slot beautifully in between the
long range plan of the company

and even the longer range
plan of the company. So if we look at a
venture company maturation at a three to five year
window, these things

are sliding into the planning
environment as we go, as the couple of years pass
through our investment.

So it turns out to work
really well as feed material for the longer range plan and
incorporating into a bigger

programs with the company. So that's how we positioned it. What people don't
know or don't see

is that, that takes
a lot of work. The team is constantly engaged
with the business units, trying

to understand what
they need, what they do, what programs
they're working on, what products
they're doing, what purchase orders they're going
to place about half our time.

So where other VCs, more
financially minded VCs, are focused on
the opportunities.

We have a lot of hand-holding
that we have to do inside. Both to make sure that
we remain relevant,

because it's easy for the
CFO just to say one day, let's shut off these funds. What are you guys doing?

So we have to be relevant. We want to hear
the business units saying that we're
doing a good job, we're bringing them
good opportunities.

And the only way
we can do that is to be in constant
communication with them, understanding what
they need to do. So it's a lot of work.

So with that in mind, how do
you make investment decisions to ensure that alignment
with the business units?

Great question, and
not a simple answer. We start off with a top level
sort of CTO list of 14 tech

areas that are very
closely aligned to the Department of Defense's
14 critical tech areas,
as you can imagine. We're a defense company. So we start there. So that's the initial screen.

Anything that slots
into one of those, we'll go try to find an
opportunity for that. But then again, on this monthly
basis, talking to the business

units, we're trying
to understand what specifically do you need? And we'll always hear some
oh, I need a 250 horsepower

thrust jet engine. OK, cool. We'll go find a company
that-- and luckily enough, we found a company.

But that's the kind of specifics
we get down to with them. So we start at a very top level,
screen things kind of fall

through. And then when we get a specific
need, we dig straight in on that and try to find
something that works.

And then do you require approval
from a business unit or just some corporate?

So it's not my first rodeo. I learned the hard
way, don't do that.

We set up the fund. So a message to
anyone who's thinking of doing a corporate fund or
any corporate funds that are

out there, I wrote a charter. I wrote a 70-page document. Describes everything that we
do, how we do it, why we do it,

what we won't do, and
got the CEO to sign that, probably because he
didn't even read it.

And in that charter,
we said that we're allowed to make investments. We've created an
investment committee.

So I have a small committee. Also, vice president
level executives that approve my
investments, but I do not

need specific business
unit approval to do it. If I did that, it would take
forever to get anything through.

I learned that in the
first fund, don't do that. I wouldn't say
we're independent.

Like I said, we are very
dependent on what they need and that gives us our focus. But when we find
a specific deal,

we don't necessarily need that. Now, if we have it,
it's great, right? If a business unit wants to
raise their hand and say,

this is the greatest
thing in the world. We'll support it. Awesome. But we probably won't
make an investment

if a business unit
stands up and says, absolutely, NFW, no way, we
probably won't make that one.

But we tend to make them-- and like I said,
we're operating. The venture world
normally operates just

outside the strategic
planning window. So we're seeing things
that are meeting needs that our VAs aren't
even aware of yet.

So sometimes, we
just see something that makes obvious sense
that we need to put in. Like we made an investment
in a solid rocket

was a problem with solid rocket
motors until Ukraine picked up. And all of a sudden,
there's a global shortage in solid rocket motors.

So we made a good bet
ahead of the need. And it's going to pay off now. Yeah.

That's great, especially as
these deals in Silicon Valley move very quickly. So what does a win look
like for your team?

The way we actually
have it set up, a win looks like the
Lockheed is now using them as a teammate or partner.

So teammate is kind of a
mushy defense world term, but are they working with us
on a proposal, a contract,

or a big program? A partner maybe, where we're
jointly developing IP with them, so their resources and our
resources pooling together

do that. But more likely or not, they're
a supplier to us somehow. That's the easiest first step. If we start buying
their wares and we

track that, I got access to all
of Lockheed's purchase orders and can read down through that,
we wrote a little bit of code

through that, so we figure out
how much money our portfolio gets in terms of operational
spending from Lockheed

every quarter, and
we report on that. So we look at that
and track that. We want it to go up into
the right, obviously.

And so far, it is. But we do track individual
company's performance on that. And then after all
that's said and done,

if we make some money
on our investment, then it's a win for us, too. And our investment
hurdle is not as high

as you might see on Sand
Hill Road down the street. Generally, we're happy with
beating Lockheed's cost

of capital, which is around 9%. Sometimes higher,
sometimes lower. So that means we'd like to
double our money in five or six

years. So that's kind of the return
that we're looking for. So we don't have to shoot
for the billion-dollar

opportunities. I just want to not be the worst
performing P&L on my CFO's P&L.

So I want to be able to
beat the cost of cash that the treasurer invests
for the company is basically

what I'm trying to do. If I do that, I'm good. Yeah. Yeah. So why don't we talk about a
couple of specific companies

that you've invested in. Firestorm, as one example. How did you source
the opportunity? How did you come to the decision
to invest in the company?

Why don't we start there? Yeah, so Firestorm
is a good one. It's a pretty recent investment,
just a couple of months old.

Firestorm is a
modular drone company, if you guys know what that
is or know Firestorm at all.

They're based in San Diego. They basically make a drone
factory in a conex box.

That's their primary product,
but it is the drones themselves that make it. They're very modular. You could put a
jet engine on it.

You could put an
electric motor on it. You could put an IFR package,
which is a surveillance package.

You could make it a
weapon if you want. So it's very
modular and flexible in terms of what it
does, which means

that it can address the needs of
several of our business areas, but more importantly, address
the needs of the customer.

And we're typically looking at
that in terms of use in Ukraine, potentially Taiwan,
and other places where

a fight may break out, and we
need to be prepared for that. We did this investment
ahead of the realization

that maybe we need to have
capability in this area. Lockheed makes some
major weapons systems

that are in use in
Ukraine right now. But what we're finding at a
dinner with General Rainey a few

months ago-- he's the head
of Army Futures Command-- he said, you know
that GMLRS round,

which is the weapon
system that we sell, is $200,000 a shot literally. It can buy a lot of
drones for $200,000.

So it became incumbent
upon us to figure out how do we augment the
systems that we provide today

with other opportunities. So, hence, Firestorm. We looked at, my gosh, there
must be a thousand drone companies.

And I think the combination
of this modularity, the field,

buildable units that
they had, the low cost that they were targeting,
seemed to be a good fit for what

we could do and
complementary to our tech and seemed like a good fit. And now, I just
heard this morning

that two of our
business groups are trying to create an RFP with
Firestorm for a government

contractor. That's right. Maybe we could talk
about another investment. That's the solid
rocket motor company.

Like I said, we sourced
that a couple of years ago. And Lockheed, at
the time, was trying to buy AJRD, Aerojet
Rocketdyne, which

ultimately went to L3Harris. And we were prevented from
buying that by the FTC.

They said they're
not going to allow these vertical
combinations anymore, so they wouldn't
let us buy them.

But at the time,
we had already seen that there was a shortage
of solid rocket motors

for a variety of
systems, whether it's spacecraft, or missile
systems, or other systems,

there are just not
enough suppliers for it. There really was AJRD
and Orbital ATK, which

was bought by Northrop Grumman. So those were the two main US
suppliers, and nobody else.

And then Ukraine
happened, and all of a sudden, demand for
these things went way up, and nobody could get anything.

And so we realized
that we needed to go find other companies
to get into this space.

And we were not
the first investor. We were, I think, the
third investor and X-Bow. But they've built out a
pretty good capability.

They won a major contract
called CPS, which is the Conventional Prompt Strike.

It was actually a large 35-inch
rocket motor for the Navy.

We're excited about where these
guys are and how they're doing. So we look at them
as immediately

being a supplier once their
stuff is qualified to use. Yeah. And then, I think-- Terran Orbita, yeah.

So this interesting
case in disruption. So Terran Orbital is a small
satellite manufacturer.

They claim, actually,
inventing the CubeSat. In fact, their first CubeSat
is now in the Smithsonian.

I was there for the
induction for that. So they may have
some claim to that. In any case, what they
did or what they enabled

is the rapid production
design and production of these small satellites. And a cubesat
could either be 1U,

which is about 10
centimeters a side, and they can go all the way
up to 16U and still be called small, which is fairly large.

Now we're talking over
a meter on a side. But what they are
able to do is create a process, sort of a mass
customization process.

They build these things
at scale and at cost. And when we did the
investment-- this is one of our
earliest investments

almost eight years ago. It was like my third investment,
I think, when I was at Lockheed.

SpaceX had just won some
government contracts, and that created a whole
bunch of other space startups.

But what the government
started to do at that time was disaggregate
large satellites. So Lockheed is the
franchise owner of GPS.

Thank you very much to all
of you who use GPS every day. Lockheed put up all
those satellites. GPS III is our franchise.

But we have several
other franchises, all in massive satellites. So GPS satellite is
over 2,000 kilograms.

It's basically a
size of a school bus. The thing is massive, right? But according to General Hayden,
they're big targets, right?

There's 27 of them. It only takes somebody
to knock three of them out to disable GPS in
that part of the globe.

So they're not as
resilient as they'd like. So the country,
the government is

interested in building much more
numerous and much more resilient assets.

And so that caught Lockheed
a little off guard. But since we made
this investment, we've won two major
contracts, $1 billion each,

with Terran Orbital. That has allowed us to perform
in that new disaggregated area

where we weren't able
to do that before. Yeah. Maybe you could share a little
bit more about post-investment.

What is the engagement with your
portfolio companies look like? It's pretty much every day.

We've built out the team. When I joined, we
had two people. Now, we've got a team of 12. So we have four
investing staff, we

have four folks that
support the investors, and then we have
four people that work 100% on post-investment, we
call integration or transition.

And transition--
nominally looks like, one, is we have a small
amount of money separate

from the investment dollars that
allows us to create projects with companies. If you're familiar with
In-Q-Tel and how they operate,

we sort of copied what they
were doing with work programs. So we create work programs
with these companies. Which is a way for
the business group

to get engaged, meet the
folks on the other side, get familiar with the tech,
maybe deploy it in some ways,

or at least, test
it in some way. And then we try very
hard now to get that tech

onto a contract with the
business group to do that. And that can take
many, many forms.

Probably every week, we hold
what's called a Lunch and Learn. So it's a Zoom-based meeting. You probably have heard
of these things before.

But we're generally
getting 200 to 250 people from across the
company on these calls. So this is where the portfolio
company presents their tech

to a wide range of
folks in Lockheed. All manner of
folks from Lockheed

Fellows down to engineering
staff, but in all the business units. And that generally
generates tons of follow up,

which then we track
through, and we try to make the connections for that. We hold an annual demo day. So we bring probably a third
of our portfolio in every year

to a central location. And then we have executive
leaders come in and meet the company they present.

You've been to demo days,
you heard about them. We run our own
internal for that. That's every year, we do that.

And then it's just a constant,
in those monthly meetings that I said, we're constantly
raising the names

of these companies with folks. If we hear something
that, oh, yes, we know this company over here. We did this, and we try
to connect the dots.

So we're sort of super
connectors within the company to get that to happen. Yeah. That's great.

That's great. So Silicon Valley
companies, we often talk about disrupting existing
ecosystems and markets.

How does your venture arm
think about disruption, considering that Lockheed's an
established part of the defense
industry? We're not immune to disruption.

We just talked about satellites. Small satellites
was a disruption. The big ones, right? Just like I keep going back
to Christensen's Innovator's

Dilemma, right. The big satellite, the
extraordinary satellite with all the bells and whistles,
that's what everyone wants.

And then along comes
this little one that can do a fraction
of what it can do, but it's cheap and resilient.

And all of a sudden, it replaces
them or complements them to a degree. So that's happened
in satellites.

We talked about
Firestorm and what's happening with missile systems. If a single round costs $200,000
and I can buy a thousand drones

for that amount, there's going
to be some trade-off there. There's going to be some
realignment of priorities

as a result of that. In Aerospace, it's
a little bit harder. And the folks that
make jets are still

a little bit immune to attack
because it's just so expensive. I mean, we're talking $5, $10
billion to field an aircraft.

And even that's outside
the range of startups, even though many, many
are trying to do that. But it's a big bite to do that.

So that's not work. And then, RMS, it's the
Rotary Mission Systems groups, basically Sikorsky helicopters.

And for years and years,
I was telling them, there's all these electric
vertical takeoff companies

out there. Aren't you interested in that? And they say, no,
those are toys. And I'm like, man, there's 200
electric helicopter companies
coming through your business. Maybe, someday, that'll happen. And now, we see a few. It's not 200, but we see a few.

Joby's got well-funded, and
Archer's got well-funded, and both went public,
actually, in the market.

And so now there's some
serious competition with some long-term funding
seems to be available to them. And now everyone's
waking up to the fact

that, hey, we should
be working with them. And we have a software package
that we develop through work

with the government called
Matrix, which is full autonomy. And nobody really has that yet. So we're working now with some
of the startups we invested in

to get that autonomy suite
on their aircraft, as well. So we're trying to make
a little lemonade out

of the lemons that
didn't happen. Is your team actively learning
from the conflict in Ukraine?

What kind of insights are
you seeing from there? Both indirectly and
directly, right? We do have folks inside
that pay attention to that,

and unclassified, we get briefed
on things that are going on. But a lot of what we read
is the same thing everyone

else reads, too. Particularly, this
last six months where the funding
wasn't approved.

The Ukrainians got
very, very creative. And what they did, how
they deployed systems,

I think we all
learned from that. I think we all learned
the vulnerability of GPS-guided
munitions to jamming

and what the Russians
are doing over there. That's giving everyone
pause about thinking, what do we need to do next?

If that fight really
happens in Taiwan, how are we going to
be prepared for that? So we are looking
for things like that.

Anti-spoofing, anti-jamming,
and inertial guidance systems. We've made an investment in
a photonic gyroscope company,

for instance, that
can help with that. So we're looking
for things that will augment systems that are
dependent on GPS today, as well.

So that's one of the
learnings that we did. And cheap is important. So how do we do things less
expensive is important.

And are there certain tech
areas that the US government is behind-- our peers in, like-- what
is your view on that?

And is your venture arm
investing in those areas?

The opposing view, a lot of the
noise we hear, oh, you know, we're behind China, behind-- I don't think so.

I don't think it's
as bad as that. I think there are
areas we can do better. I think there are areas in terms
of bioengineering that we're

behind on, and Lockheed's
not big in that space, but we see lots of
deals going through,

and we're not participating. So I think that's
an area to work on. I think some of the more
advanced autonomy things

around swarming-- I mean, people think swarming
is flying in formation. No, it's a lot more.

It's an intelligent being. And I haven't seen a single
company working on it to the way it needs to
be to be able to resist

an attack on that. And then the other
area that we've learned now is Counter-UAS.
How do we defeat these swarms?

How do we defeat these
small drones coming in? I don't think we have adequate
systems for that right now.

Across the board, we don't
have adequate systems for that to work on that. So how do you think about
balancing investing resources

in new tech versus kind of just
responding to calls from DOD that might not be
as cutting edge

as the state of the industry? So we try to pay
attention to it. Because the DOD,
again, a misperception

is that, they're always
behind the times. If you start looking
at DARPA papers,

you realize they're
actually a decade ahead of the rest of the world. They have people that think
about some amazing stuff long,

long before that. So we wrote some code to mine
all the DARPA solicitations. We look for keywords.

We try to find new tech on that. And we're actually
getting leads from that. We're not behind.

Actually, we're ahead. But where they fail
is that transition of that early research
into capabilities.

They may do an interesting
paper, get a great study, get a result, but then
what happens next?

Where does it go? How does it get into a
system or get into a program? So there are gaps
even in that process.

But in terms of the
thinking, they're brilliant in what they look at.

So do you have any
thoughts on DOD's tendency to spend a lot more capital
stopping threats that

are a fraction of a cost, like
[INAUDIBLE] IDs, small drones, just really expensive
to mitigate,

but not expensive to employ? And how should we
address these sort of-- Yeah, they're really
aware of that.

Again, that dinner
with General Rainey, he's really aware
of the asymmetry. You don't want to send a
million-dollar missile to take

out a $2,000 drone, right? We can only do that for so long. Ultimately, it will
be economic fight.

Whoever has the bigger
economy will win. And that's not where
they want to be. They want to be in
a position where

they appear so strong that the
attack doesn't even happen. That's why we're
a defense company, because we want to prevent
the offense from happening.

So they're well aware of that. I think these threats
are recently emerging. I mean, we could have
theorized that this stuff would

happen a long time ago. But I think watching Ukraine
and see them really play out, seeing a small drone or a
javelin missile take out

a $5-million tank or something
and do it routinely has really opened some eyes. I mean, it even
caused the Marines

to say we're getting
rid of all our tanks. So it is causing a force
correction that are going on.

And we're starting to see
the same thing in the Navy and other forces, as well. They're just trying to catch
up to how tech has evolved

at the speed that it has. But they're well aware of
this asymmetric problem. They don't want to spend
money like that, doing that.

I think the Israelis
are seeing it in the conflict they're
dealing with right now, too.

So is there anything
that you're looking at that the US government
isn't, that you think

they should be looking at? No, not really. Like I said, they're
pretty advanced, pretty

broad-based in
what they look at. I mean, I'm frustrated
like anyone.

Like, I have this dual role. I'm trying to get these
companies to work with Lockheed, but I'm also trying to get them
to work with the US government.

And the rate of uptake in the
government is very slow, right? But for good reason. When you think about it,
again, back to General Rainey

said, when I buy
something, I have to equip 58 divisions
with this stuff. So this is massive
amount of procurement,

and they want to
make sure it works. And they don't want to get out
58 divisions worth of stuff,

and then have it fail. So that's the
challenge, is how do you

support these
small companies who need a constant flow of revenue
at a time when we really

know how to feel fast
changing-- and meaning, fast to obsolescence technology?

And that's the challenge, I
think, they all have right now. Do we do 10 divisions,
and then wait and see, and then do 10 more?

Or do we all do 58? So I think that's the challenge. I don't have that problem, too. Because when
Lockheed's not buying,

then I want them to be a
supplier to the government, as well. And we fight that same
battle, as everyone else does,

to make that happen. Yeah. Yeah. So what advice do you have
for the next generation of founders in the room?

And especially folks looking
to work at the intersection of technology innovation?

I'm a corporate
venture capitalist, and a lot of my friends over on
Sand Hill Road don't like us.

Just so that you know that. They generally give
you advice not to work with us early in their life.

You've co-invested
in two companies with one of my colleagues. Yeah. But I honestly think that is
rather inane and simple advice.

you actually should
be doing two things. Think of two things. You're not only trying
to get their money, you're interviewing them.

You want to understand why
are they investing in me? Why do they decide to
write me that check? And that is never more important
than with a corporate investor.

Because I'm a
strategic investor. So ask me, what's your strategy? Why are you investing in me?

And if you're aligned,
it's going to be great. You're going to get access. We have 125,000 employees,
70,000 engineers,

1,000 of them are top technical
talent probably in the world in the areas they work on. You'll get access to that.

So not bad, right? But if we're not aligned, and
we want to take you that way

and you want to go that way,
probably not a good fit. You probably shouldn't
take their money. So interview your
investor, as well.

And every corporate
is not the same. We tend to be painted with
one brush from Sand Hill Road?

We're not. We're all different. Every company you meet is going
to have a different strategy. Some are going to lean
much more to the financial.

We're kind of right of center
on financial versus strategic. So we're a little bit more
strategic than financial.

Just make sure you know
what that company is about. So interview them. What is your strategy?

Why are you investing in us? And try to understand
why that is. And even with financial VCs. You ought to ask what's
your expectation?

I hear, I want you to be a
billion dollars in two years. Well, is that even possible?

Because you're going to
get those kind of pressures to do it. I think it's just a bias to
not have corporates in the mix

early on. But again, not for
everybody, but don't just exclude this group of
folks just because somebody

said to exclude them. I think you use your
own wits about you, find out what their strategy is. And if it's aligned well
with what you're doing,

then it could be a really
great relationship, and you could benefit
greatly from it.

So maybe final question,

that we can provide to founders. Maybe in two sentences, what

provides to you, founders, can

provide to founders? Well, yeah, hopefully, we've
talked about a lot of it, so beyond the money that
we provide as investors--

and we tend to stay
with the companies for a number of rounds, so
we're not a one-and-done kind of investor.

We want the company to succeed. I tell people, if you take
our money, all of a sudden, I work for you.

It's the weirdest thing. I pay you, and I work for you. So once we're
invested-- and we really

take that to heart--
we are invested. We will get your name
in front of everybody who is even remotely interested
in that technology, in Lockheed,

and any government
person that we walk in front of that
we are aware that needs that kind of technology.

So we will work tirelessly to
promote you within the company and without the
company to do that.

And like I said, we
have a little bit of money available
to create activities. And aside from the investment,
to create activities

within the company. But we generally don't give up. We tend to work very hard,
and everyone looks-- at least,

half their job is
promoting the portfolio of companies within Lockheed. Yeah. And you get in front
of a lot of folks.

Get in a lot of folks, yeah. Great. Well, why don't we open
it up for questions?
Let's see. Let's get him. He's right there. All right.

I'm just curious. First of all, thank
you for coming today. Sure. [INAUDIBLE] think this is on.

Is it on? Just yell. OK. Thank you for coming today. I was just curious,
how do you think about your role
in the venture arm

as it relates to some of the
corp dev and M&A functions? I know a lot of CVCs
are kind of combined. How do you think about
that relationship?

So he's asking, how do we look
at our relationship versus corp dev and some of

It's a great question. We work very hard
to actually have a continuum of capabilities.

So I work on the earliest
stage activities. We're doing seed to series A,
series B for our first check.

We'll do other
checks after that. But for the first check, we
like to be early in that. We created a group
in December that's

called LM Evolve, which is, I
guess, in business school terms, it would be a growth equity
group, kind of private equity.

So they're looking at
growth stage investing. And very few of
our companies are going to pass
through to that that

look like they're
both strategically relevant to Lockheed
but also growing, and they have additional
capital available for that.

And then corp dev, the
traditional corp dev is JVs and M&A. The structured
relationships, JVs and M&As,

and some of the growth capital
things will migrate to that. Not too many. Lockheed's been doing
ventures since 2007.

I think we've invested
in 95 different companies over that time. We haven't bought any.

So I don't know, maybe
that's a bad indictment. I haven't made anything
attractive enough. But generally, we're
trying to build up

the defense industrial base. So buying them and
making them part of us doesn't necessarily do that. So creating a strong supplier
is really number one for us.
Good. Anything else?

I can also just yell. Obviously, Anduril has been
going on a buying spree, acquiring quite a few companies.

And now, they've won
one of the two finalists for the CCA program.

How does that impact
your engagement with the industry in terms
of a lot of small companies?

Particularly, the
defense tech world will say like, we want to

it looks like Anduril

wants to be the
Anduril for everything. How is that impacting your job?
Good for them, right? Honestly, good for them.

Of all the companies
that I've seen, there are purpose-built
defense company, and there are not
a lot of those.

A lot of them are
what we call dual use, meaning they have a
commercial side and that. And those folks are really
focused entirely on defense.

And again, I've spent 30
years in semiconductor, so I'm mostly commercial. So coming over here, a lot
of this was foreign to me.

But I just realized the way
government procurement works out is very odd.

And it's lumpy, and as you
know, politically motivated. And so you may have
a contract one year, and then all of a sudden, it's
half the size of the next year,

and then it's triple
the size the next year. So how do you build
a company on that? So the only way to do that
is what Anduril is doing--

buy a bunch of product
lines, and so that they're all counter cyclical, right? So underlying that,
you've got this kind

of norm business level. So they're doing
the right thing. Any company who's got one
product and dependent on that,

you hear this term Valley
of Death and other things. Yeah, you're going
to see wild cycles. And unless you have great
investors who are supporting you

through those down
periods, you're probably going to
go out of business. But Anduril is trying to
create multiple cycles

with different businesses,
so I think it's good. So I saw Palmer at a
conference in Palm Springs

a couple of months ago. And always, those guys are
always give me a hard time, and I always give
him a hard time.

But I said to
Palmer, Palmer, who do you think is Lockheed's
biggest supplier? And he had no idea.

I said, it's Northrop. Like, whoa. I said, we're going to be
working together some day. If you really are
going to be a prime,

we're all going to
be working together because that's the way the
government contracts work. So I think the more the merrier.

They're going to bring
a whole bunch of suite of new capabilities to the
defense industrial base that everyone will benefit from.
So I think it's good.
Again? All right. She raised her hand. Let's do her first.

Hi, thank you for being here. My question was that, how do

Our interests in AI are both
broad, like everyone's, and very narrow in terms of
edge processing.

So we've done a
couple of investments in Edge AI compute, more
inference engine-type things

because some of the

very quickly at the Edge.

So that's one bracket of
things that we look at. On the large size, we're
partnered with Nvidia.

You're in Nvidia's
building here. So Jensen speaks often at the
meetings that we have, and we

work with them. I mean, why not go to
the best to do that? So probably not the domain
of my world to do that.

The dollars are
big, the companies are maturing at that point,
but we are looking consistently along the Edge at things
that will work in that area.

Are you focused
your energy anywhere in this case of quantum
computing or things like that? Yeah, we have actually
three quantum investments.

We did D-Wave years ago,
long before I was there, Atom computing, and
what's the third one?

[? IN-Q. ?] So three
different modes, three different modalities. Again, I'm using a
semiconductor paradigm.

I think, ultimately, who's
going to win in that space? Who can make a qubit
cheaper than anyone else the same way that
happened in the SEMI World?

The jury's still out on
where that's going to be. I think [? IN-Q ?] is reasonably
far ahead at this point,

but we'll see. Atom's got, with
their neutral ion computing has potential to
have much less error and a leg

up on the other folks. But there's new
tech out there, too. We've seen photonic
computing, and we haven't invested in those. So those are the three bets that
we took right now to do that.

I think Lockheed bought a
D-Wave machine 15 years ago. And we run the quantum computing
center at USC with them.

So we've been deep into
quantum for a long, long time. Yeah.

Way in the back. Sir, thank you for being here. A question related to

in terms of the
thinking, but failing to transition that

maybe going from early stage
R&D to actually being a company that you'd be

Yeah. I've said this many, many
times in other forums. The government does
not look like a market,

and it needs to look
more like a market. It needs to look like
a consistent series of requirements
and buying patterns

that will allow capital to flow. I mean, it's not. It's very inconsistent in
the way it makes decisions.

And I think that defeats
some of those early tech because they don't
see the demand signal from the
government at that point.

And I think that's where
the gap really lies. And there's an expert
on this over here.

This guy in the front,
he knows all this stuff. He taught me everything I know. [CHUCKLES]

But that's the
biggest problem I see is why would capital flow to
something where the customer is

unsure whether they
want to buy it or not? That would never happen in
the commercial space, right? In fact, a lot of the diligence
that a venture capitalist will

do is on the market, on the
customer, talk to customers. Why are you buying this? What makes sense?

How much are you going to buy? I actually went to the NGA,
the National Geospatial

Organization. We were looking
at SAR companies, and I was trying to figure
out what's the market for SAR?

And they're probably the
biggest buyer of that stuff. So I went right to the
head there and asked them,
are you interested in SAR? Yes. All right. Will you buy SAR? Yes. How much will you buy?

Can't tell you. How much will you pay? Can't tell you. And you want me to invest in
this constellation, right?

Yes. Like, what? How? I mean-- so that's
kind of the scenario that we have on a lot
of stuff like that.

We just have no idea. So even we're perplexed
by that stuff, too. You can see the need.

You can map out
the mission space where it's going
to fit in there, but then, the dollars don't

And there's some, maybe,
a little place, but-- We're doing along fine, but it's

They don't like us there. And I'm like, why? Yeah. And there is some aspect of the

We've probably
led less than 10%. We're allowed to lead, but

that you want that
other perspective. You want somebody who's

That's a horse, that's

So it's good to
invest with others, and financially minded folks are
great to bring in at that point.

We're trying to do it. When I was looking at the
data a couple of weeks ago,

about a third of the things
that we actually invest are referred by other VCs. So we're brought
into a lot of deals.

And as I mentioned, we've got
some of the top technical talent in the world on areas around

and space. If we're doing a

That's a massive radar on

person to the meeting.

We hardly get a word
in at that point because the people go into

But we'll bring those people. We'll bring the

So tell me which VCs

So they bring us in because

Back there.

Given the only
other alternative, I guess, to dual use
is looking abroad to allies and other militaries.

How do you think about
that path for startups being able to serve
US militaries?

It's an excellent
question, and one, again, that I put forth every time
I'm in front of a government

this program called AUKUS, which is Australia, US, and
UK, which is starting

to open up a channel
to allow tech to flow more freely between them. So you're exactly right. So it actually is
the other way around.

So if we see a small
but really good defense tech company
in Australia today,

there may be rules on export
controls, or ITAR, or whatever, that prevents that from being
used in the United States.

But if AUKUS opens up that
channel, then all of a sudden, the US market becomes
available to them. And all of a sudden,
it's a big opportunity

like we talked about. As opposed to only selling
into the Australian market.

And I've heard now that these
channels are opening up, that things are
starting to break free, allowing that to happen.

So there may be, in
the very near future, free flow of technology
between at least those three countries,
and Canada, too.

I mean, you can't exclude
Canada out of that. So open that up, that
opens up a bigger market.

The other opportunity is NATO. NATO has an investment
fund now, too. And they're trying
to get that tech

to be used amongst the 32 Allied
Nations in NATO to do that. We've yet to see that happen.

The fund is brand new,
so hopefully, they're able to do that. But that's another channel
to get that to happen. But you're exactly right.

If you can't sell here or your
home country is too small, if you can sell abroad with
the right controls in place,

then that's a great way
to do this, as well. Yeah. Sure.

So SpaceX obviously
really disrupted United Launch
Alliance, which was a joint venture between
Boeing and Lockheed Martin.

What do you think went wrong? And what do you think what could
have Lockheed Martin done t

build a better space platform? What do you think your
role is in helping

prevent a SpaceX from
disrupting Lockheed Martin now?

That's a loaded question. [LAUGHTER] So a couple of years
ago, I was at ULA,

talked with Tory Bruno,
the CEO, and asked him, why don't you land
your first stage?

And he said, we already
know how to do that. We designed that a decade ago. The government didn't
want to pay for it,

so we never deployed it. So it's not like
everything's that innovative

that SpaceX is doing. It's just that they had
the guts to actually do it. And they were going to do it
on an investor dollars versus--

this is the problem. This is what we see, too. The disruption
that Lockheed sees

is that the source of
capital is very different. Lockheed has to fund most of
their programs out of profit

on other programs
that they make. Whereas, a lot of
startups are funding it based on investor interest
in the tech to make it go.

So it's a little bit
unfair in that way. We were joking the other-- when the first Starship
went up and blew up,

we're like, oh my
god, that blew up. And then the news
articles kept coming

out saying how SpaceX viewed
that as a big success. And we're like, wow, if
we blew up a ULA rocket,

we'd be shut down. Everything would be off. There'd be
congressional reviews.

So it's two different worlds. I mean, it's hard to
make that comparison. It's easy when you stand
back and look at that,

but you're operating in two
entirely different worlds-- the government contracting
world, and then

the venture-fueled world
where risk is acceptable and failure is OK, as
opposed to the world

where failure really is not OK. I mean, they don't
want anything to fail. So there are constraints
that you have

to deal with in that space. But it's not because
they're not innovative. People keep labeling
Lockheed as not innovative.

We just went to an
asteroid 250 million miles away, picked up a sample,
and brought it home,

and landed it within
three meters in when we said we were going to land it. 10 years ago when the
mission was planned.

And then they were
so good about it, they sent the pod carrier off
to check out another asteroid

because they had enough
fuel left to go do that. And that was all planned here in
Palo Alto from the group in ATC,

over here did that. So they can do some
pretty amazing stuff. It's not for lack of innovation
that we are what we are,

what we do. Do that. Yeah. You mentioned the slow
and somewhat frustrating

nature of working
with the government. Do you notice a
significant difference between presidential
administrations,

or is it kind of
establishment DOD in DC? I haven't seen it.

I mean, a lot of the
programs got established. We were just looking
at this morning. There's 117 organizations
in the government now

that can actually access
SBIR dollars and OTA dollars.

So these are the small
contracting vehicles that are mostly used with
small companies and startups. So that's up from probably 30
when I started eight years ago.

It's a huge number
of organizations can now write
contracts themselves. And I don't think
that's significantly

changed between administrations
one way or another. All right.
Great. So Chris, let me--

Now the hard question. No, no, no questions. I'm just going to summarize the
goodness of this conversation. So for all of you
in the room who've

been going to all these
weekly events, what you're hearing tonight is
another piece of the puzzle.

We heard from In-Q-Tel. We have two world-class defense
investors, Ernestine and Paul

Kwan from General Catalyst. And all this has
kind of emerged. And Eric Volmar, who started
the Office of Strategic Capital

and the ability to do loans
for a billion dollars,

that just never existed five
years ago, even two years ago. And you're all recipients of an
ecosystem that is just emerging,

and emerging at scale. And it's there for all of you. Lockheed is a
critical part of it.

And I would say this, when Chris
wasn't here, probably the most innovative prime
contractor, I would say,

for dealing with startups. Certainly better
than the ones that would know Boeing,
Raytheon or RTX, et cetera.

But the problem is,
some of you mentioned is the impedance mismatch
between that creative side

of funding and the way
the government deals with buying things. It turns out the government
still starts with requirements.

And a requirement says, I
not only know the problem, I know the solution. So here's the spec,
give it to me.

And that makes all the
sense in the world. When you could predict the
technology, the threats, the whatever, and that tends to
work with how they're organized,

which are around program
executive officers called PEOs, who manage
existing sustaining programs.

And they do what are called
great Horizon 1 and 2 innovations. How do I make my
existing product better?

We mentioned Aegis. How do I make the radar a
little better, et cetera? Or how do I disconnect
Aegis from the platform

and put Aegis in a box
that's Horizon 2 innovation? But to see again, to make
a pun, over the Horizon

3, the things that you mentioned
that are not a requirement. But you guys see.

That's a real problem in
trying to convince a defense department who they
aren't dumb people, but they don't have
a process to do that.

And Chris, I'm sure, deals
with that internally, as well. Your organization is designed
to fulfill requirements,

and every once in a
while, might come up with an unsolicited
proposal that comes from some innovation you do.

So my suggestion to all of you
is, at the end of this quarter, back up a bit, and
hopefully, we could summarize

all the pieces you've heard. And then, back to you,
try to understand,

what's going on in the defense
department as a customer? And then you'll understand
this, how do you fit in?

Do you want to be a
defense-only supplier? Boy, you ought to
understand, it's

not about your shiny object. It's about understanding
how the DOD buys? What your go-to market
strategy will be?

Or else, you'll be a kind
of funded shiny object that goes out of business. Or you'll be a
partner with Lockheed

who will help you understand how
that system works through Paul Kwan at General Catalyst who
are experts at understanding,

how do you sell to the
Department of Defense? Does that make
sense to all of you? And again, what you heard
tonight is, as I said,

I think the best practices of
a corporate venture capitalist in the defense arena, and Chris,
it's kind of a double threat.

Because as you said, the
part I would not pass up is he spent 30 years in the
commercial space understanding

how to sell and build ecosystems
for commercial companies, and now doing it
again for defense.

So, Chris, thank you very much. I thought incredibly insightful. We keep running into each other
at almost every good meeting.

And I learned everything he
thinks he learns from me. I actually copy from him. So thanks again, Chris.
